child.pub-comments: All four Kadai languages are of the monsyllabic, isolating type, with full tonal systems as in Thai. The Kadai word-order, like that of Thai and Indonesian, shows object following verb, and modifying elements (including genitive constructs) following modified elements' (580).

child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1942. Thai, Kadai, and Indonesian: A New Alignment in Southeastern Asia, American Anthropologist, 4 edn., vol. 44, 576-601. New Jersey: Wiley-Blackwell.

child.pub-comments: Throughout the article, the author refers to this subgroup as "Indonesian" until page 599, in fotenote 55, where he refers to it as "Austronesian." Based upon the languages that Benedict hypothesizes are the children of this group, the Austronesian code was the logical one to use.

child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1942. Thai, Kadai, and Indonesian: A New Alignment in Southeastern Asia, American Anthropologist, 4 edn., vol. 44, 576-601. New Jersey: Wiley-Blackwell.
Benedict, Paul K. 1942. Thai, Kadai, and Indonesian: A New Alignment in Southeastern Asia, American Anthropologist, 4 edn., vol. 44, 576-601. New Jersey: Wiley-Blackwell.
child.pub-comments: Annamite, too, takes its proper place as the northeasternmost member of the Mon-Khmer stock' (599-600).

root.pub-comments: The writer accepts Schmidt's posulation of an Austric superstock including Mon-Khmer and Austronesian, even though this relationship has not yet been thoroughly demonstrated' (599).
